awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Shrub Impacts on Nitrogen Inputs and Turnover in the Arctic, and the Potential Feedbacks to Vegetation and Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecosystems develop and change through interactions between living organisms and their physical environment. A shift in vegetation is one of the most important changes an ecosystem can experience, because it can alter exchanges of energy (originating from sunlight), water, and elements such as carbon and nitrogen, among air, plants, and soil. In the Arctic, a widespread shift from tundra to shrub-dominated vegetation appears to be occurring. This research project will discern whether, through complex interactions, this transition to shrublands in the Arctic is likely to result in the release of more carbon into the air (as either carbon dioxide or methane, which are both greenhouse gases). Vast amounts of carbon are stored in Arctic and northern soils, so reduced carbon storage in the Arctic may affect weather and climate in other parts of the world. 

This project will assess the contributions of different shrub feedbacks to carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) cycling. Snow depth will be manipulated with existing snow fences across a natural gradient of shrub density and height, and a new snowfence experiment will be established in alders. Shrub-induced changes in soil C over the longer term in one ecosystem will be examined in an 18-year-old species removal experiment. Shrub growth, primary production, and biomass will be measured. Long-term effects of added snow on ecosystem N partitioning and shrub N uptake will be measured in a 15N tracer experiment. N fixation will be measured in alder populations and moss communities associated with shrubs. The relative strengths of different shrub feedbacks to N availability and uptake by vegetation will be evaluated. This project will improve prediction of the consequences of shrub expansion in the Arctic, and its potential impacts on regional and global climate. Results will contribute to training of graduate and undergraduate students, to public outreach and training of K-12 teachers and students, and to development of a web-based resource for education.

por.por_cntn:
Ecosystems develop and change through interactions between living things and their physical environment. A vegetation shift is one of the most important changes an ecosystem can experience, because it can alter exchanges of energy (originating from sunlight), water, and elements such as carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) between air, plants, and soil. In the Arctic, a widespread shift from tundra to deciduous shrub-dominated vegetation appears to be occurring. Arctic shrublands may take up more C through photosynthesis than tundra does, yet store less C, if a transition to shrubs promotes decomposition of soil organic matter (SOM), and thus, release of C to the air (as either CO2 or methane, both greenhouse gases) more than it promotes C uptake. Vast amounts of C are stored in arctic and boreal soils, so reduced C storage in the Arctic may affect weather in other parts of the world, and global climate.  Because C and N cycles are linked tightly in arctic ecosystems and plant growth is limited by soil N availability, shrubs affect soil C through their effects on near-surface soil N. Shrubs influence both N release from SOM by decomposition and N inputs. Shrubs may increase SOM decomposition by altering both the physical environment and the quality of new SOM. Snow trapping by shrubs in winter insulates the soil, increasing soil temperature and promoting overwinter decomposition. Shrubs also alter decomposition through the quality and quantity of their leaf litter, which increase soil N availability compared to leaf litter from graminoid-dominated tundra. Crucially, Siberian alder, the arctic shrub whose expansion is best documented, engages in symbiotic N fixation from N2 gas in the air, which could greatly increase N inputs to soil. Shrubs also affect moss community composition, and potentially, moss-associated N fixation. We aimed to assess contributions of different shrub feedbacks to C and N cycling in the Arctic.

            Intellectual Merit: We found that Siberian alder promotes SOM turnover in arctic soils through its N inputs, as assessed by soil enzyme activities; this was true at our main arctic site, but not in boreal sites with alder, where soil C appeared to be more recalcitrant, perhaps because alder has been established in these boreal sites for longer. This suggests that expansion of alder in the Arctic may destabilize soil C. However, Siberian alder individuals growing in our arctic sites were up to 142 years old, so had not established recently. When analyzing their growth using dendrochronology, we found that their age had a strong influence on the sensitivity of their growth to temperature. Older alders were more sensitive than younger alders, perhaps because they have greater capacity for growth in good years, but also suffer from higher maintenance respiration costs, leading to worse growth in poor years. In tundra with deciduous shrubs but no alder, we found that vegetation composition does have a strong effect on ecosystem C storage; in a field experiment manipulating species composition, we found that after 20 years, treatments with a higher abundance of deciduous shrubs retained substantially less C than treatments with a higher abundance of evergreen shrubs.  The difference was similar to that seen where permafrost is thawing, and about half the loss induced by N fertilization in tundra over the same time frame. Our collaborator identified N fixation in association with a wide variety of moss species in tundra, indicating that this may be a significant source of N inputs in shrubby locations without alder.  Finally, we discovered a truly novel response of shrubs to snow, where loaded shrub and tree branches of species from northern regions bend more at subfreezing temperatures than at temperatures above freezing, even though they are stiffer. This bending improves survival of shrub buds over the winter by enabling shrub branches to lie down beneath the snow surface, thus protecting buds from damage due to wind, low temperature, and herbivory by birds. This bending also helps taller trees and shrubs shed snow from their branches. This result is counter-intuitive, and affects the distribution of snow across the landscape, as well as survival of shrubs.

            Broader Impacts: This project improved our understanding of how shrubs influence C and N cycling in the Arctic, which is relevant to predicting how changing vegetation will modify feedbacks from arctic ecosystems as climate continues to warm.  Adapting to and mitigating climate change is perhaps the most crucial challenge that humankind faces in the next century.  This project contributed to the education of three graduate students (two at UAF, one at NAU), six undergraduate (REU) students who did independent projects, and 10 undergraduate students at UAF who gained research experience by working in the lab processing plant samples. We collaborated with two K-12 teachers to bring information from this research into their curricula. This project promoted career development for three investigators, two of whom are female.
